content.html:
I am very curious about Hebrew, specially the way the language is hierarchically designed. Three letter words are commonly known as trilateral roots and the rest of the words are variation of these three letters and categorized under the same family. I am not going to get into these details since it is not the scope of this post.

Long story short, the journey of trying to learn Hebrew started probably between 2006 to 2008 and I haven’t had much success at it. Or lets say that the expectations don’t match reality =P. So I thought that I could try to somehow start with the most common words in the scriptures and that is what motivated to parse the Aleppo codex and analyze its content in python. I quickly learned that my approach was rather naive given the prefixes that causes variations to the words, even thought the meaning of the word itself is the same.

This blog post is a second attempt to tackle the same problem but with a more sophisticated linguistic approach using Text Fabric.

A corpus of ancient texts and (linguistic) annotations represents a large body of knowledge.

Text-Fabric is a Python package for processing and access a corpus of ancient text and linguistic annotations. In this specific case I am using the Hebrew Bible Database, containing the text of the Hebrew Bible augmented with linguistic annotations compiled by the Eep Talstra Centre for Bible and Computer, VU University Amsterdam.

The text is based on the Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia edited by Karl Elliger and Wilhelm Rudolph, Fifth Revised Edition, edited by Adrian Schenker, Â© 1977 and 1997 Deutsche Bibelgesellschaft, Stuttgart.

The text-fabric version has been prepared by Dirk Roorda Data Archiving and Networked Services, with thanks to Martijn Naaijer, Cody Kingham, and Constantijn Sikkel.

It is amazing to see the work these researchers did compiling all this data and making it public for free. I am very thankful for it.

I am using a literate programming approach with Doom Emacs and org-mode.

Create the virtual environment

virtualenv ~/.workon-home/venv-textfabric
cd ~/.workon-home/venv-textfabric
source ./bin/activate.fish
pip install text-fabric pandas requests

Activate the virtual environment

Use C-c here on Doom Emacs

(pyvenv-activate "~/.workon-home/venv-textfabric")

Load the ETCBC/bhsa dataset

Use run-python and ober-eval-block-in-repl to evaluate each block (C-c r at the time being). For the sake of a more practical approach to writing using literate programming the output of the blocks will follow the code.

from tf.app import use
import os
import collections
from itertools import chain

A = use("ETCBC/bhsa", hoist=globals())

A.indent(reset=True)
A.info("counting objects ...")

for otype in F.otype.all:
    i = 0

    A.indent(level=1, reset=True)

    for n in F.otype.s(otype):
        i += 1

    A.info("{:>7} {}s".format(i, otype))

A.indent(level=0)
A.info("Done")

**Locating corpus resources ...**
app: ~/text-fabric-data/github/ETCBC/bhsa/app
data: ~/text-fabric-data/github/ETCBC/bhsa/tf/2021
data: ~/text-fabric-data/github/ETCBC/phono/tf/2021
data: ~/text-fabric-data/github/ETCBC/parallels/tf/2021

   |     0.05s  426590 words
  0.15s Done

Analizing some lexemes

Text-Fabric allows to query the “types” of words. We can do this by using:

print(F.sp.freqList())

(('subs', 125583), ('verb', 75451), ('prep', 73298), ('conj', 62737), ('nmpr', 35607), ('art', 30387), ('adjv', 10141), ('nega', 6059), ('prps', 5035), ('advb', 4603), ('prde', 2678), ('intj', 1912), ('inrg', 1303), ('prin', 1026))

Defining some help functions

These functions will facilitate the processing of the data. The first one will get the occurrences of a specific type of lexeme. I am not a linguist so I am learning on the go and I will try to explain it easily. The most common lexeme verb is ×××¨ (say). It appears 5307 times. We can see that Yah indeed wants to communicate and instruct us.

A specific instance of that verb has other properties (node features) like morphology which contains the verbal stem (qal, piel, nif, hif), the verbal tense (perf, impf, wayq) and gender (m, f) among other information.

import pandas as pd

def get_lexeme_by_type(lex_type):
    rows = []
    A.indent(reset=True)
    #A.info("Collecting data")
    for w in F.otype.s("lex"):
        if F.sp.v(w) != lex_type:
            continue
        row = {'w': w,
               'freq_lex': F.freq_lex.v(w),
               'sp': F.sp.v(w),
               'lex_utf8': F.lex_utf8.v(w),
               #'g_word_utf8': F.g_word_utf8.v(w),
               'gloss': F.gloss.v(w),
               #'gn': F.gn.v(w),
               #'nu': F.nu.v(w),
               #'ps': F.ps.v(w),
               #'st': F.st.v(w),
               #'vs': F.vs.v(w),
               #'vt': F.vt.v(w),
               #'book': F.book.v(w),
               }
        rows.append(row)
    #A.info("Done")
    df = pd.DataFrame(rows)
    return(df)

def pp_sorted_df(input_df, rows_qty):
    sorted_df = input_df.sort_values(by=['freq_lex'], ascending=False)
    output_df = sorted_df.head(rows_qty)
    return([list(output_df)] + [None] + output_df.values.tolist())

Printing the most frequent verbs (lexemes)

Here is a list with the top 100 verbs sorted by frequency.

verbs = get_lexeme_by_type('verb')
print_df = pp_sorted_df(sorted_verbs, 100)

Here we can see the id of the lexeme (w), the frequency (freq_lex), the utf8 representation of the word without vowel pointing and the english meaning used for the translation. All automatically, pretty cool isn’t it?

  • Top 12 verbs with strongs

    Out of those, I wanted to map also the pronunciation, Strong numbers and the full meaning from BLB so I created this table. Note that the strong number as the pronunciation are just probable, since I am working with lexemes rather than words.

    Pronun. Word Qty Meaning Strongs

    shaw-mah' ×©×××¢ 1168 to hear, listen to, obey WLC H885
    daw-bar' ×××¨ 1143 to speak, command, promise, warn, threaten, sing KJV H1696
    yaw-shab' ××©×× 1082 to dwell, remain, sit, abide KJV H3427
    yaw-tsaw' ××¦× 1069 to go out, come out, exit, go forth KJV H3318
    shoob ×©××× 1056 to return, turn back KJV H7725

    I made this list by hand, which is not very practical for automation, so I wonder if there is a better way to get the Strong numbers automatically. I don’t have an answer for this at this time, but this repository looks promising: https://github.com/eliranwong/BHS-Strong-no/blob/master/brief_info_ETCBC_lex.csv.

    I still have some work that is not documented, so this is work in progress. I am still learning how to properly use TF’s API.

    As a side note I also found word by word on BHS 5th edition here: https://github.com/eliranwong/MP3_BHS5_word-by-word. I am very excited about this finding. Also it is worthwhile checking out this: https://github.com/eliranwong/UniqueBible.
content.text:
I am very curious about Hebrew, specially the way the language is hierarchically designed. Three letter words are commonly known as trilateral roots and the rest of the words are variation of these three letters and categorized under the same family. I am not going to get into these details since it is not the scope of this post.
Long story short, the journey of trying to learn Hebrew started probably between 2006 to 2008 and I haven’t had much success at it. Or lets say that the expectations don’t match reality =P. So I thought that I could try to somehow start with the most common words in the scriptures and that is what motivated to parse the Aleppo codex and analyze its content in python. I quickly learned that my approach was rather naive given the prefixes that causes variations to the words, even thought the meaning of the word itself is the same.
This blog post is a second attempt to tackle the same problem but with a more sophisticated linguistic approach using Text Fabric.
A corpus of ancient texts and (linguistic) annotations represents a large body of knowledge.
Text-Fabric is a Python package for processing and access a corpus of ancient text and linguistic annotations. In this specific case I am using the Hebrew Bible Database, containing the text of the Hebrew Bible augmented with linguistic annotations compiled by the Eep Talstra Centre for Bible and Computer, VU University Amsterdam.
The text is based on the Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia edited by Karl Elliger and Wilhelm Rudolph, Fifth Revised Edition, edited by Adrian Schenker, Â© 1977 and 1997 Deutsche Bibelgesellschaft, Stuttgart.
The text-fabric version has been prepared by Dirk Roorda Data Archiving and Networked Services, with thanks to Martijn Naaijer, Cody Kingham, and Constantijn Sikkel.
It is amazing to see the work these researchers did compiling all this data and making it public for free. I am very thankful for it.
I am using a literate programming approach with Doom Emacs and org-mode.
Create the virtual environment virtualenv ~/.workon-home/venv-textfabric cd ~/.workon-home/venv-textfabric source ./bin/activate.fish pip install text-fabric pandas requests Activate the virtual environment Use C-c here on Doom Emacs
(pyvenv-activate "~/.workon-home/venv-textfabric") Load the ETCBC/bhsa dataset Use run-python and ober-eval-block-in-repl to evaluate each block (C-c r at the time being). For the sake of a more practical approach to writing using literate programming the output of the blocks will follow the code.

ques; mult) nametype â ï¸ named entity type (pers; mens; gens; topo; ppde.) nme â nominal ending consonantal-transliterated (absent; n/a; JM, ...) nu â grammatical number (sg; du; pl; NA; unknown.) number â sequence number of an object within its context otype pargr ð hierarchical paragraph number (1; 1.2; 1.2.3.4; ...) pdp â phrase dependent part-of-speech (art; verb; subs; nmpr, ...) pfm â preformative consonantal-transliterated (absent; n/a; J, ...) prs â pronominal suffix consonantal-transliterated (absent; n/a; W; ...) prs_gn â pronominal suffix gender (m; f; NA; unknown.) prs_nu â pronominal suffix number (sg; du; pl; NA; unknown.) prs_ps â pronominal suffix person (p1; p2; p3; NA; unknown.) ps â grammatical person (p1; p2; p3; NA; unknown.) qere â word pointed-transliterated masoretic reading correction qere_trailer â interword material -pointed-transliterated (Masoretic correction) qere_trailer_utf8 â interword material -pointed-transliterated (Masoretic correction) qere_utf8 â word pointed-Hebrew masoretic reading correction rank_lex â ranking of lexemes based on freqnuecy rela â linguistic relation between clause/(sub)phrase(atom) (ADJ; MOD; ATR; ...) sp â part-of-speech (art; verb; subs; nmpr, ...) st â state of a noun (a (absolute); c (construct); e (emphatic).) tab â clause atom: its level in the linguistic embedding trailer â interword material pointed-transliterated (& 00 05 00_P ...) trailer_utf8 â interword material pointed-Hebrew (Ö¾ ×) txt â text type of clause and surrounding (repetion of ? N D Q as in feature domain) typ â clause/phrase(atom) type (VP; NP; Ellp; Ptcp; WayX) uvf â univalent final consonant consonantal-transliterated (absent; N; J; ...) vbe â verbal ending consonantal-transliterated (n/a; W; ...) vbs â root formation consonantal-transliterated (absent; n/a; H; ...) verse â verse number voc_lex â vocalized lexeme pointed-transliterated (B.: R;>CIJT BR> >:ELOHIJM) voc_lex_utf8 â vocalized lexeme pointed-Hebrew (×Ö¼Ö° ×¨Öµ××©×Ö´××ª ××¨× ×Ö±×Ö¹×Ö´××) vs â verbal stem (qal; piel; hif; apel; pael) vt â verbal tense (perf; impv; wayq; infc) mother â linguistic dependency between textual objects oslots Phonetic Transcriptions phono ð phonological transcription (báµ rÄÅ¡ËÃ®á¹¯ bÄrËÄ ÊáµlÅhËÃ®m) phono_trailer ð interword material in phonological transcription 0.00s counting objects ... | 0.00s 39 books | 0.00s 929 chapters | 0.00s 9230 lexs | 0.00s 23213 verses | 0.00s 45179 half_verses | 0.01s 63717 sentences | 0.01s 64514 sentence_atoms | 0.01s 88131 clauses | 0.01s 90704 clause_atoms | 0.03s 253203 phrases | 0.03s 267532 phrase_atoms | 0.01s 113850 subphrases | 0.05s 426590 words 0.15s Done Analizing some lexemes Text-Fabric allows to query the “types” of words. We can do this by using:
print(F.sp.freqList()) (('subs', 125583), ('verb', 75451), ('prep', 73298), ('conj', 62737), ('nmpr', 35607), ('art', 30387), ('adjv', 10141), ('nega', 6059), ('prps', 5035), ('advb', 4603), ('prde', 2678), ('intj', 1912), ('inrg', 1303), ('prin', 1026)) Defining some help functions These functions will facilitate the processing of the data. The first one will get the occurrences of a specific type of lexeme. I am not a linguist so I am learning on the go and I will try to explain it easily. The most common lexeme verb is ×××¨ (say). It appears 5307 times. We can see that Yah indeed wants to communicate and instruct us.
A specific instance of that verb has other properties (node features) like morphology which contains the verbal stem (qal, piel, nif, hif), the verbal tense (perf, impf, wayq) and gender (m, f) among other information.
import pandas as pd def get_lexeme_by_type(lex_type): rows = [] A.indent(reset=True) #A.info("Collecting data") for w in F.otype.s("lex"): if F.sp.v(w) != lex_type: continue row = {'w': w, 'freq_lex': F.freq_lex.v(w), 'sp': F.sp.v(w), 'lex_utf8': F.lex_utf8.v(w), #'g_word_utf8': F.g_word_utf8.v(w), 'gloss': F.gloss.v(w), #'gn': F.gn.v(w), #'nu': F.nu.v(w), #'ps': F.ps.v(w), #'st': F.st.v(w), #'vs': F.vs.v(w), #'vt': F.vt.v(w), #'book': F.book.v(w), } rows.append(row) #A.info("Done") df = pd.DataFrame(rows) return(df) def pp_sorted_df(input_df, rows_qty): sorted_df = input_df.sort_values(by=['freq_lex'], ascending=False) output_df = sorted_df.head(rows_qty) return([list(output_df)] + [None] + output_df.values.tolist()) Printing the most frequent verbs (lexemes) Here is a list with the top 100 verbs sorted by frequency.
verbs = get_lexeme_by_type('verb') print_df = pp_sorted_df(sorted_verbs, 100) w freq_lex sp lex_utf8 gloss 1437621 5307 verb ×××¨ say 1437611 3561 verb ××× be 1437637 2629 verb ×¢×©×× make 1437773 2570 verb ××× come 1437669 2010 verb × ×ª× give 1437760 1547 verb ××× walk 1437623 1298 verb ×¨×× see 1437812 1159 verb ×©×××¢ hear 1438048 1138 verb ×××¨ speak 1437900 1082 verb ××©×× sit 1437657 1068 verb ××¦× go out 1437844 1038 verb ×©××× return 1437764 965 verb ××§× take 1437799 944 verb ×××¢ know 1437724 890 verb ×¢×× ascend 1437851 847 verb ×©××× send 1437769 835 verb ×××ª die 1437768 810 verb ××× eat 1437628 732 verb ×§×¨× call 1437894 653 verb × ×©×× lift 1437884 629 verb ×§×× arise 1437736 583 verb ×©××× put 1438023 548 verb ×¢××¨ pass 1438442 521 verb ×¢×× stand 1437899 500 verb × ×× strike 1437767 494 verb ×¦×× command 1437835 492 verb ××× bear 1437766 468 verb ×©×××¨ keep 1437775 453 verb ××¦× find 1437776 434 verb × ×¤× fall 1438193 377 verb ××¨× descend 1437782 376 verb ×× × build 1437819 370 verb × ×× report 1439047 347 verb ××× be king 1437816 332 verb ××¨× fear 1437682 327 verb ××¨× bless 1438467 316 verb ×¢× × answer 1438536 303 verb ×¤×§× miss 1438046 297 verb ×¡××¨ turn aside 1437685 292 verb ××× be full 1438495 290 verb ×××§ be strong 1438067 288 verb ××¨×ª cut 1437722 288 verb ××¨×©× trample down 1438906 225 verb ××§×©× seek 1437684 224 verb ×¨×× be many 1439718 223 verb ××ª× write 1438074 217 verb ×©××ª× drink 1439180 216 verb ××× be firm 1438225 214 verb complete 1439443 205 verb ××©××¢ help 1438002 204 verb ××¡×£ gather 1438392 202 verb ×©××¤× judge 1438251 193 verb ××× be able 1438014 188 verb ×¨×× be high 1438077 188 verb ××× uncover 1438323 140 verb ×§×¨× encounter 1438461 135 verb ×¤× × turn 1438010 135 verb ×¤×ª× open 1437937 134 verb ××× defile 1438923 134 verb ××× slaughter 1438373 133 verb ×§××¨ bury 1438020 133 verb ×©×××¨ remain 1437856 129 verb ×©××× dwell Here we can see the id of the lexeme (w), the frequency (freq_lex), the utf8 representation of the word without vowel pointing and the english meaning used for the translation. All automatically, pretty cool isn’t it?
Top 12 verbs with strongs
Out of those, I wanted to map also the pronunciation, Strong numbers and the full meaning from BLB so I created this table. Note that the strong number as the pronunciation are just probable, since I am working with lexemes rather than words.
Pronun. Word Qty Meaning Strongs aw-mar' ×××¨ 5379 To say, speak, utter KJV H559 haw-yaw ××× 3561 to be, become, come to pass, exist, happen, fall out KJV H1961 aw-saw' ×¢×©×× 2629 to do, fashion, accomplish, make KJV H6213 bo ××× 2570 to go in, enter, come, go, come in KJV H935 naw-than' × ×ª× 2017 to give, put, set KJV H5414 haw-lak' ××× 1554 to go, walk, come KJV H1980 raw-aw' ×¨×× 1298 to see, look at, inspect, perceive, consider KJV H7200 shaw-mah' ×©×××¢ 1168 to hear, listen to, obey WLC H885 daw-bar' ×××¨ 1143 to speak, command, promise, warn, threaten, sing KJV H1696 yaw-shab' ××©×× 1082 to dwell, remain, sit, abide KJV H3427 yaw-tsaw' ××¦× 1069 to go out, come out, exit, go forth KJV H3318 shoob ×©××× 1056 to return, turn back KJV H7725 I made this list by hand, which is not very practical for automation, so I wonder if there is a better way to get the Strong numbers automatically. I don’t have an answer for this at this time, but this repository looks promising: https://github.com/eliranwong/BHS-Strong-no/blob/master/brief_info_ETCBC_lex.csv.
I still have some work that is not documented, so this is work in progress. I am still learning how to properly use TF’s API.
As a side note I also found word by word on BHS 5th edition here: https://github.com/eliranwong/MP3_BHS5_word-by-word. I am very excited about this finding. Also it is worthwhile checking out this: https://github.com/eliranwong/UniqueBible.

name: Analyzing the Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia with Text Fabric in Python
summary:
I am very curious about Hebrew, specially the way the language is hierarchically designed. Three letter words are commonly known as trilateral roots and the rest of the words are variation of these three letters and categorized under the same family. I am not going to get into these details since it is not the scope of this post.
Long story short, the journey of trying to learn Hebrew started probably between 2006 to 2008 and I haven’t had much success at it.
